Award.AwardTitle: RET Site: Computing Research Experiences for STEM Teachers (CREST)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for a new Research Experiences for Teachers (RET) Site focused on robotics at the University of California-Davis. Forty five in-service and pre-service computer science and STEM teachers will be paired with faculty mentors to conduct cutting-edge research related to computing and robotics during a six week summer program. The RET teachers will also develop curricular materials for the integration of computing concepts into STEM disciplines and implement related research-based activities in their classrooms during the academic year. The program includes two sequences of workshops and a summer symposium to explore the impact on the teachers' knowledge, experiences, and instructional practice and to reach out to other teachers in the local community. The RET Fellows will become master teachers and assist in providing other secondary school teachers with professional development in computing, thereby broadening the impact and sustainability of the project.

Intellectual merit: The intellectual merit of this project lies with the strong research mentor team and excellent infrastructure at the university for the project. The project builds on prior research and pilot studies. The projects are compelling and of current interest and are exciting for teachers and their students. The new research-based curriculum implemented In schools during the academic year should provide important research-based methods for developing computational thinking competencies at the K-12 level.

Broader impacts: The program plans to target in-service teachers from the Yolo county school district as well as pre-service education students at the university. The target schools have a large population of underrepresented and economically disadvantaged students who will be impacted. National and international dissemination of the results and the curricular materials will open the pathways for replication and broader impact that is pervasive and fundamental to moving the underlying concepts into the K-12 arena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Computing Research Experiences for STEM Teachers (CREST) project has created an enduring partnership between K-12 school science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) teachers and UC Davis faculty mentors and C-STEM Center to promote teachers’ professional development and create a teaching “infrastructure” that stimulates and inspires them to effectively guide their students towards computing and STEM related careers and post-secondary study.

Forty-five in-service and pre-service computer science and STEM teachers (15 per year for 3 years) participated in the project as CREST Fellows. These CREST Fellows were trained in robotics and computer programming using the C/C++ interpreter Ch for problem solving, paired with faculty mentors to experience cutting-edge research related to computing, and developed curricular materials for the integration of computing in STEM subjects in a six-week summer program each year. UC Davis faculty mentors and their students supported Fellows to implement research project-based computing and engineering activities in their classrooms during the academic year. Fellows and their students showcased their accomplishments on the UC Davis C-STEM Day competitions in the Spring.

After C-STEM Day 2015 we asked the students from CREST Fellows with high levels of implementation to take an altitudinal survey. Amongst students with high exposure, 78% agreed knowing about robotics is important and 86% agreed knowing about computer programming is important. This represents an increase of 11 and 7 percentage points over students’ pre-course ratings for robotics and computer programming, respectively. Student interest in science careers increased from 33 to 41 percent; engineering increased 41 to 52 percent, technicians increased 41 to 52 percent, computer scientist/programmer increased 32 to 49 percent and mathematicians increased from 23 to 32 percent.
